title: [FEATURE] Add Label Predictions for `Sentence Transformers` within `ArgillaTrainer`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

labels.name: team: interns
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the machine learning interns team

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
For the Sentence Transformers framework within the ArgillaTrainer, `predict()` only makes sentence similarity predictions using cosine similarity. However, for the NLI task, the sentences must be labeled with one of the categories like a textcat task. Another problem this creates is: for an NLI task, there is a premise and a hypothesis and the task is to decide whether the hypothesis is inferred from the premise or not. By using similarity, there will be no specific hypothesis or premise, rather both sentences will be the same in terms of being inferred from each other.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add a method/parameter to predict NLI data by labeling them into categories, i.e. entailment, contradiction, neutral. Here is an example:

```
loss_model = SoftmaxLoss(model=model, sentence_embedding_dimension=model.get_sentence_embedding_dimension(),num_labels=3)

for step, batch in enumerate(train_dataloader):
  features, label_ids = batch
  for idx in range(len(features)):
    features[idx] = batch_to_device(features[idx], model.device)
  label_ids = label_ids.to(model.device)

  with torch.no_grad():
    _, prediction = loss_model(features, labels=None)

model_prediction = torch.argmax(prediction, dim=1)
```


**Describe alternatives you've considered**

**Additional context**

title: [BUG] Cannot add `metadata_property` if `Dataset.is_ready`

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
**Describe the bug**

It seems that the `configure_metadata_property` of any search engine defined as `SearchEngine` is not working as expected, as it fails when calling `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/metadata-properties` once the `FeedbackDataset` is published in Argilla i.e. `Dataset.is_ready`.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**

To reproduce one can either do that via the API creating a `FeedbackTask` dataset with or without `metadata_properties`, and after publishing it, trying to add a new and completely different `metadata_property` to the dataset. Or alternatively, one could also use the code at #3900 and do that programatically via the Python client as follows:

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(
    api_url="http://0.0.0.0:6900",
    api_key="argilla.apikey",
)

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="text", required=True)],
    questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="question", title="What is the question?", required=True)],
)

remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")

remote_dataset.add_metadata_properties(
    metadata_properties=[
        rg.FloatMetadataProperty(name="float_metadata", min=0., max=1.),
        rg.IntegerMetadataProperty(name="integer_metadata", min=0, max=10),
        rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="terms_metadata", values=["term1", "term2", "term3"]),
    ],
)

```

**Expected behaviour**

The `FeedbackTask` dataset should support adding new `metadata_properties` to existing datasets.

**Environment:**

```
╭─ Argilla Info ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ Connected to http://0.0.0.0:6900                                                                                                                                                                │
│                                                                                                                                                                                                 │
│  • Client version: 1.17.0a0                                                                                                                                                                     │
│  • Server version: 1.17.0a0                                                                                                                                                                     │
│  • ElasticSearch version: 8.5.3                                                                                                                                                                 │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
```

title: [BUG]  FeedBack record ID is getting overridden with an autogenerated uuid internally by Argilla
body:
**Describe the bug**

- The FeedBackRecord class has the option to send the user given ID as the record identifier with id as parameter - [Code Ref](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/40dc948ec563bee8ea8ef2f6c1f09d7d1718ebcd/src/argilla/client/feedback/schemas.py#L138)
- The issue is the user given ID is getting overridden with an autogenerated uuid internally by Argilla.
[](url)

**Code to create the bug**

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init("<API url>", "<API key>")

record_identifier = "<UUID generated by us>"
record = rg.FeedbackRecord(
    id=record_identifier,
    fields={},
    metadata={},
)

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_argilla(name="<dataset-name>", workspace="<workspace-name>", with_records=False)
dataset.add_records(record)
dataset.push_to_argilla()

dataset.fetch_records()

record_found = False
for record in dataset.records:
    if record.id == record_identifier:
        record_found = True
        break

if not record_found:
    print(f"Record with id {record_identifier} not found")
else:
    print(f"Record with id {record_identifier} found")
```


**Expected behaviour**

- There should be an option for the user to give the record identifier for the FeedbackRecord similar to TextClassificationRecord
- ID given by the user should be the record identifier and it should not be overridden by Argilla 


**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version: 1.13.2
 - OpenSearch Version: 2.5
 - Docker Image: argilla/argilla-server:v1.13.2

**Describe the bug**

The `FeedbackDataset` uploaded to the Hugging Face Hub at https://huggingface.co/datasets/argilla/oasst_response_comparison is using a `TextQuestion` to ask the annotator to rank certain fields, while it could now use the `RankingQuestion` instead.

Taking into consideration that this dataset is being used in the `Dockerfile.quickstart` image as a default example, would be nice to actually showcase the Argilla feature to do that, rather than an outdated workaround.

**Expected behaviour**

The `FeedbackDataset` to be exported to the Hugging Face Hub using the `RankingQuestion` instead of the `TextQuestion`.

## Which page or section is this issue related to?

In the following documentation page https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/getting_started/quickstart_workflow.html#2.-TokenClassification, the documentation is there on how to configure the dataset settings for the `DatasetForTextClassification`, but it's missing for the `DatasetForTokenClassification`, so we should be adding the following snippet there too, under the `TokenClassfication` section.

## Code snippet

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(
    api_url="<API_URL>",
    api_key="<API_KEY>",
    workspace="admin",
)

settings = rg.TokenClassificationSettings(label_schema=["PER", "ORG", "LOC", "MISC"])
rg.configure_dataset_settings(name="token-classification-dataset", settings=settings)

rg.log(rg.TokenClassificationRecord(text="Hello world!", tokens=["Hello", "world", "!"], name="token-classification-dataset"))
```

title: [FEATURE] progress visibilty for the annotaiton progress
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Yes the problem is regarding cross visibility for an annotation team, Currently with feedback datasets that support situations like multi task multi label and other complex tasks, labeling can be a tough challenge for annotators especially non domain experts, They might need guidance and reviews from principal annotators, thus progress visibilty is essential aswell as admin access to edit annotations in datasets that are truly shared with a single record per annotation. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Annotators with admin role can view annotation progress in a better manner so anotator roles can get the work reviewed. (especially feedback datasets. ) The same annotators also have the ability to edit responses in the dataset in 'annotator' workspace.

title: [BUG] Cannot delete metadata fields

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->


**Describe the bug**

I am trying to delete metadata by editing the records' metadata in python and syncing via `rg.log`, but the deleted metadata from the record persists in the server after `rg.log`, therefore I cannot delete metadata.

**To Reproduce**
```python
import argilla as rg
rg.init(api_url="...", api_key="...")
rg.set_workspace("ivan")

# Create dataset with one record (example) with some metadata
record = rg.Text2TextRecord(
    text="example text",
    annotation="example annotation",
    metadata={
        "metadata_field_1": True,
        "metadata_field_2": "foo",
    }
)

# Upload
rg.log(record, "test_dataset")

# Download 
dataset = rg.load("test_dataset")
len(dataset)  # 1
record = dataset[0]
record.metadata  # {'metadata_field_1': True, 'metadata_field_2': 'foo'}

# Delete metadata field locally
del record.metadata['metadata_field_2']
record.metadata  # {'metadata_field_1': True}

# Upload (sync)
rg.log(record, "test_dataset")
```

Output:

```
Logging... ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━   0% -:--:--

1 records logged to http://.../datasets/ivan/test_dataset

BulkResponse(dataset='test_dataset', processed=1, failed=0)
```

If we download again:

```python
dataset = rg.load("test_dataset")
record = dataset[0]
record.metadata  # {'metadata_field_1': True, 'metadata_field_2': 'foo'}  -> Wasn't deleted when doing rg.log
```



**Expected behavior**
The deleted metadata of the record gets deleted from remote when doing `rg.log`. In other words, deletion persists


<!-- Since version 1.16.0 you can use `python -m argilla info` command to easily get the used versions -->
**Environment (please complete the following information):**
```
!python3 -m argilla info

╭─ Argilla Info ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ Connected to http://localhost:6900/                                           │
│                                                                              │
│  • Client version: 1.16.0                                                    │
│  • Server version: 1.14.0                                                    │
│  • ElasticSearch version: 8.5.3                                              │
╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
```

title: feat: add validation layer for `metadata_properties` and `metadata_filters`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR adds a validation layer for both the `metadata_properties` when `metadata` is provided via `FeedbackRecord` when adding that record to either a local or existing `FeedbackDataset`, as well as validating the `metadata_filters` provided to the `filter_by` method for `RemoteFeedbackDataset`.

These validation layers would help reduce the API workload as the validation will be done client-side, which implies that the client will handle the validation first.

In this case, as we have the following properties: `TermsMetadataProperty`, `IntegerMetadataProperty` and `FloatMetadataProperty`; we'll need to ensure that the values provided for those are correct, both on `add_records` and also on `filter_by`.

The approach is similar to the one already implemented for the `fields` of a `FeedbackRecord`, but extending it to the `metadata_properties` to also include a validation layer that ensures not just the type of the value provided, but whether it's compliant with the pre-defined values for `TermMetadataProperty` or the pre-defined boundaries for both `IntegerMetadataProperty` and `FloatMetadataProperty`. The core difference is that besides the `pydantic` validation, there's also a method in each property that validates the values provided in the filters related to those metadata properties.

Closes #3859

**Type of change**

- [X] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Add unit tests for the `generate_pydantic_schema_for_metadata` method
- [x] Add unit tests for both `_validate_filter` and `_pydantic_field_with_validator` in each property i.e. `TermsMetadataProperty`, `IntegerMetadataProperty`, and `FloatMetadataProperty`
- [x] Add unit tests for `add_records` with both correct and wrong `metadata`
- [x] Add integration tests for `add_records` and `filter_by` to ensure that the validation is correct both before and after applying those ops

**Checklist**

- [ ] I added relevant documentation
- [X] follows the style guidelines of this project
- [X] I did a self-review of my code
- [ ] I made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [X] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [ ] I filled out [the contributor form](https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK) (see text above)
- [x] I have added relevant notes to the CHANGELOG.md file (See https://keepachangelog.com/)

labels.name: type: enhancement

body:
## Description

A validation layer should be included for both the `metadata_properties` and the `metadata_filters` (linked with the pre-defined `metadata_properties`) on both `add_records` and `filter_by` methods, respectively.

This validation will help on detecting the problem on the user-side to avoid calling the API with wrong payloads, and also to help the user debug it better.

title: fix: allow `required=False` fields to be logged in Argilla

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
# Description

This PR addresses an issue with the Argilla API, since it's not handling optional values passed as e.g. `{"required": "text", "optional_value": None}` neither when those optional fields are not provided as part of the payload e.g. `{"required": "text"}`.

So on, in the PR the API validation when creating new records has been fixed to check that the optional fields are neither None nor str, instead of applying the same check as for the required fields; plus improving the `to_server_payload` method in the `FeedbackRecord` schema not to include the fields with value None.

Closes #3845

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Add unit tests for the validation on the API-side when creating records via `validate_record_fields`

body:
# Description

This PR adds a `sort_by` query parameter to the `GET /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records`, `GET /api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records` and `POST /api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records` that allows to sort the records by using the `inserted_at`, `updated_at` or a metadata property, either in ascending or descending order.

In addition, this PR adds the `parse_query_param` function that is meant to be used as an endpoint dependency using `fastapi.Depends`. The function is able to parse query parameters with the format: `key1,key2,key3` or `key1:value1,value2,value3`.

title: [FEATURE] Add `metadata_properties` to `push_to_huggingface` and `from_huggingface`

labels.name: type: integration
labels.description: Indicates integrations with third parties

body:
## Description

As of the recent addition of the `metadata_properties` to the Python client at #3818 by @gabrielmbmb, we need now to ensure that those are preserved and dumped as part of the configuration that is uploaded to the Hugging Face Hub when exporting a `FeedbackDataset` via `push_to_huggingface`, as well as making sure that it's properly restored when pulling a `FeedbackDataset` from the Hugging Face Hub via `from_huggingface`.

## Solution

We should add `metadata_properties` as an optional attribute for the `DatasetConfig` class, and ensure that both the serialization and deserialization to/from YAML includes the `{Terms,Integer,Float}MetadataProperty` schemas with the fields required to restore those later i.e. `name`, `description`, and `values` for `TermsMetadataProperty` or `min` and `max` for `{Integer,Float}MetadataProperty`

## Description

As of the recent development of the `metadata_properties` and `metadata_filters` in the API, we should ensure that those are covered in the Python client too.

The `metadata_properties` were already covered at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3818 by @gabrielmbmb, but the `metadata_filters` were still pending, so this issue is to add those into the `filter_by` method of `RemoteFeedbackDataset` datasets i.e. `FeedbackDataset` datasets pushed to Argilla.

title: feat: adapt active learning with small-text example to recent argilla version
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR solves #3442 in which two notebooks should be updated. In the respective issue I just wanted to raise the small-text version since there have been new features, and more importantly, some bug fixes in small-text.

In the course of updating this, I noticed that the notebooks seemed to have issues when used with a recent argilla version:
1. a legacy warning regarding `rg.configure_dataset()`
2. an error regarding `TextClassificationRecord` which was passed `id`s of type np.int64, which seems to have become stricter and now requires int. 

This could have been done in ~~two~~ three PRs but since it needs manual testing afterwards I decided to count it as "one update".  I hope you are okay with this ;). *Edit: I made separate entries in CHANGELOG.md. Feel free to rewrite/change it back.*

The following two notebooks were updated:
- [tutorials/notebooks/training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.ipynb](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/6d997f74251f72381f5145edd5877cfea611e300/docs/_source/tutorials/notebooks/training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.ipynb)
- [tutorials/notebooks/deploying-textclassification-colab-activelearning.ipynb](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/6d997f74251f72381f5145edd5877cfea611e300/docs/_source/tutorials/notebooks/deploying-textclassification-colab-activelearning.ipynb)

Changes:
- Raised small-text version
- Replaced the call to `rg.configure_dataset()` with `rg.configure_dataset_settings()`
- Changed ids to be of type int
- Dataset name (i.e. the "project" in argilla) now uses hyphens instead of underscores to keep it consistent with the default project in hugging face spaces' argilla template.

Closes #3442

**Type of change**

- [x] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- `training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.ipynb` has been tested with a local Jupyterlab against a Hugging Face Spaces argilla instance.

body:
# Description

This PR contains some bug-fixes and improvements as a follow up for https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3784.

* `FeedbackDataset` from the Hugging Face Hub fails if exported with an outdated version as it still contained the ID for some columns

title: [BUG] `TextClassification` dataset displays the labels in wrong order

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
**Describe the bug**
When setting the `label_schema` for a `TextClassification` dataset the order in which the labels were provided is lost.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
import argilla as rg

rg.set_workspace("admin")

settings = rg.TextClassificationSettings(label_schema=[
    "1 (extremely positive/supportive)",
    "2 (positive/supportive)",
    "3 (neutral)",
    "4 (hateful/unsupportive)",
    "5 (extremely hateful/unsupportive)",
    "6 (can't say!)"
])

rg.log(rg.TextClassificationRecord(text="blablabla"), name="test-order-labels")

rg.configure_dataset_settings(name="test-order-labels", settings=settings)
```

![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/29572918/a930e62f-43de-4dc0-9e86-6fb7bef6cd4d)

**Expected behavior**
The order in which the labels were provided is not lost.

<!-- Since version 1.16.0 you can use `python -m argilla info` command to easily get the used versions -->
**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.16.0
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: 8.8.2
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]:

title: [REFACTOR] Move everything from `argilla/client/feedback` into `argilla/feedback`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Describe the solution you'd like**

As of the addition of the `ArgillaTrainer` for the `FeedbackDataset` datasets at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3151, the `argilla/feedback` module was created to define user-friendly imports as `argilla.feedback` instead of `argilla.client.feedback`.

Now the idea is to move everything to `argilla/feedback` to avoid having potentially duplicated imports and also to avoid confusion between both modules.

**Additional context**

This should be tackled once all the priorities are completed, and ideally we should keep some `DeprecationWarning`s for the stuff on `argilla.client.feedback` if applicable, because all the references point directly to `import argilla as rg` rather than the implicit imports instead.

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the machine learning interns team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

When pushing a `FeedbackDataset` to Argilla there's not much information shown so the push may feel transparent, so ideally we should print out some sort of information once a `FeedbackDataset` is pushed to Argilla.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

The relevant information to be shown as a table formatted with `rich` containing information such as the name, workspace, URL, # of records, etc. following a similar format to how it's done in the CLI e.g. `argilla datasets list`.

**Additional context**

This issue has been created as a follow up of https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3120, suggested by @dvsrepo, and is potentially related/dependant of https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3823

title: [FEATURE] Use `rich` and `tqdm` for better logging bars

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

When uploading or downloading records from Argilla for the `FeedbackDataset` from the Python client, the current `tqdm` bars are not as nice as the former ones, so we should either bring back those or propose a new cool formatting when pulling records.

Ideally this should just happen when calling the `pull` method (to be renamed to `pull_from_argilla`) from a `RemoteFeedbackDataset` i.e. a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla.

Also those bars should be present when pushing a `FeedbackDataset` to Argilla for the first time via `push_to_argilla` and when adding records to an existing `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla i.e. a `RemoteFeedbackDataset`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

A solution that combines `rich` and `tqdm` in a similar way as for the `rg.log` function that was being used to upload the records on the former datasets i.e. `DatasetForTextClassification`, `DatasetForTokenClassification`, and `DatasetForText2Text`.

**Additional context**

This issue has been created as a follow up of https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3120, suggested by @dvsrepo

title: [DOCS] Add page in the docs describing Argilla user roles

labels.name: type: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

body:
## Which page or section is this issue related to?

Right now Argilla has three roles for its users: owner, admin and annotator. We've briefly mention about these roles in several pages of the documentation, but it would be good to have an specific page describing the roles (basically what each role can do and what cannot do)

This image can be used as a reference (thanks @dvsrepo!):
![Argilla roles table](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/29572918/959e0724-73ea-4ffa-9a59-6cd275180056)
